pageContext.claim: “Violent crime is way down, murders in America's largest cities dropped by six percent between 2017 and 2018.”
pageContext.analysis: In his presidential campaign, Trump hyped a brief increase in the murder rate, falsely claiming "we have the highest murder rate in this country in 45 years.” Now, as president, he's trying to take credit for statistical noise. He often refers to a six-percent decline, which is a carefully-parsed figure. It refers not to crime or even across the country; it's the one year decline in the murder rate in America’s largest cities. The overall murder rate has barely changed under Trump, going from 5.4 per 100,000 people in 2016 to 5.3 in 2017, or a decline of 1.4 percent. 2018 statistics show crime has declined under Trump, but they are not at the lowest level they have ever been — rather they have been fairly stagnant — with slight increases and decreases — for more than a decade.
